description: West Berkshire Council is in discussions with neighbouring local authorities over joining forces.
title: West Berkshire Council bids for devolution merger
title_page: West Berkshire Council bids for devolution merger - BBC News
maintext:
A council is in discussions with a number of its neighbours about the possibility of joining forces as it looks into different options to deliver local government reorganisation.
West Berkshire is talking to Berkshire's five other councils - Bracknell Forest, Reading, Slough, Windsor and Maidenhead, and Wokingham councils, as well as South Oxfordshire and Vale of White Horse in Oxfordshire, as part of a government shake-up of local government, external.
It said merged authorities could pool resources and provide a better service to residents.
West Berkshire Council's leader Jeff Brooks said: "In Berkshire we are no stranger to reorganisation, having seen the county council disbanded through local government reforms almost 30 years ago."
Mr Brooks continued: "We evolved successfully then to meet the challenges of the time and we shall do so again now - together with, and on behalf of, local people."
West Berkshire provides services to about 170,000 people but the government wants councils to be much bigger, covering a population of 500,000 instead.
The government also wants local authorities to provide it with initial proposals by 21 March, before handing over final plans by the end of November.
